body: I will think about this, but it's not a first priority for now. I never tried using parallel streams with I/O in practice, but I think that there are not so many tasks where such change will be useful. If you have small file with CPU-consuming per-line processing, then reading it to the `List` sequentially, then process in parallel would be much better. You will not keep the file open during the whole operation, so you free the file handler faster (there are limited number of them usually) and file gets unlocked faster on Windows. If you have really big file, so reading it into memory seems to be unreasonable, then current spliterator strategy should work well. Anyways if we propose a new strategy, then it will be at least no worse than existing one for the most of common usages, thus extensive testing would be necessary.

I committed an optimized general purpose [IteratorSpliterator](https://github.com/amaembo/streamex/commit/16e1c2ecfc5d214c1feea6b953ccfbeb505ea273) for iterators of unknown size. Some benchmarking results are here:

```
(parallel) (impl)  (n)       Score     Error  Units
     true  base      3       4.973 ±   0.142  us/op
     true  base     10       9.882 ±   0.128  us/op
     true  base     30      18.633 ±   1.027  us/op
     true  base    100      46.394 ±   1.753  us/op
     true  base    300     163.285 ±   5.719  us/op
     true  base   1000     496.049 ±   5.257  us/op
     true  base   3000    1944.159 ±  40.606  us/op
     true  base  10000    6916.634 ± 116.902  us/op
     true  jdk       3       3.499 ±   0.162  us/op
     true  jdk      10       8.191 ±   0.184  us/op
     true  jdk      30      23.898 ±   0.543  us/op
     true  jdk     100      79.470 ±   1.810  us/op
     true  jdk     300     295.881 ±  15.301  us/op
     true  jdk    1000     817.950 ±  11.145  us/op
     true  jdk    3000    2954.316 ± 120.163  us/op
     true  jdk   10000    7970.635 ± 175.836  us/op
     true  opt       3       2.768 ±   0.105  us/op
     true  opt      10       7.877 ±   0.131  us/op
     true  opt      30      15.094 ±   2.210  us/op
     true  opt     100      47.337 ±   1.638  us/op
     true  opt     300     187.816 ±   8.407  us/op
     true  opt    1000     577.947 ±  12.567  us/op
     true  opt    3000    2317.630 ±  31.987  us/op
     true  opt   10000    7497.548 ± 170.823  us/op
    false  base      3       1.807 ±   0.015  us/op
    false  base     10       5.540 ±   0.025  us/op
    false  base     30      18.449 ±   0.497  us/op
    false  base    100      62.752 ±   1.968  us/op
    false  base    300     273.997 ±  17.264  us/op
    false  base   1000     876.322 ±  53.642  us/op
    false  base   3000    3633.522 ± 301.100  us/op
    false  base  10000   13811.535 ± 394.655  us/op
    false  jdk       3       2.208 ±   0.066  us/op
    false  jdk      10       6.519 ±   0.500  us/op
    false  jdk      30      22.797 ±   0.815  us/op
    false  jdk     100      71.748 ±   4.562  us/op
    false  jdk     300     310.781 ±   1.379  us/op
    false  jdk    1000     813.416 ±  24.592  us/op
    false  jdk    3000    3082.675 ±  44.448  us/op
    false  jdk   10000   11969.098 ± 946.530  us/op
    false  opt       3       2.197 ±   0.043  us/op
    false  opt      10       6.223 ±   0.421  us/op
    false  opt      30      21.203 ±   1.403  us/op
    false  opt     100      70.029 ±   3.649  us/op
    false  opt     300     283.029 ±  22.234  us/op
    false  opt    1000     928.026 ±  51.289  us/op
    false  opt    3000    3741.137 ± 190.673  us/op
    false  opt   10000   13142.609 ± 224.455  us/op
```

This is `map(...).collect(Collectors.toList())` with quite CPU-consuming `map` operation. The `base` is `ArrayList.spliterator` which is very fast and should parallelize ideally. The `jdk` is `Spliterators.spliteratorUnknownSize` and `opt` is my new implementation. As you can see, for parallel streams my implementation is consistently better especially when the stream size (n) is approaching to `1024`. The problem I fixed is the transition from iterator mode to array mode. JDK spliterator splits badly at this point: it returns the `ArraySpliterator` while the original spliterator remains of zero size. This results in uneven tasks distribution. My spliterator supports both array mode and iterator mode and during the transition it changes itself as well.

More testing (and probably some minor optimization) is necessary, but for now results look quite promising. Meanwhile you can checkout the [optimized-iterator](https://github.com/amaembo/streamex/tree/optimized-iterator) branch and test it by yourself.

One more benchmark on different PC (previous was Core Duo, this one is Core Quad):

```
(parallel)  (task) Bench   (n)     Score     Error  Units
      true    trim base      3     4.388 ±   0.074  us/op
      true    trim base     10     4.758 ±   0.063  us/op
      true    trim base     30     5.563 ±   0.061  us/op

      true pattern opt    3000  1028.520 ±  59.679  us/op
      true pattern opt   10000  3500.588 ± 172.535  us/op

      true pattern jdk      30    15.863 ±   0.240  us/op
      true pattern jdk     100    52.176 ±   0.280  us/op
      true pattern jdk     300   205.931 ±   0.881  us/op
      true pattern jdk    1000   650.993 ±   6.407  us/op
      true pattern jdk    3000  2008.242 ± 119.288  us/op
      true pattern jdk   10000  3729.162 ±  77.707  us/op
     false    trim base      3     0.160 ±   0.001  us/op

     false    trim base   3000    74.723 ±   0.598  us/op
     false    trim base  10000   251.570 ±   2.004  us/op

     false    trim opt   10000   268.170 ±   1.764  us/op

     false    trim jdk   10000   262.285 ±   2.556  us/op
     false pattern base      3     1.526 ±   0.016  us/op

     false pattern base     30    14.952 ±   0.190  us/op
     false pattern base    100    50.237 ±   0.154  us/op
     false pattern base    300   202.622 ±   1.001  us/op
     false pattern base   1000   651.412 ±   8.618  us/op
     false pattern base   3000  2549.271 ±  44.269  us/op
     false pattern base  10000  9604.081 ± 677.764  us/op
     false pattern opt       3     1.488 ±   0.015  us/op
     false pattern opt      10     4.828 ±   0.028  us/op
     false pattern opt      30    14.933 ±   0.100  us/op
     false pattern opt     100    50.249 ±   0.206  us/op
     false pattern opt     300   205.956 ±   2.160  us/op
     false pattern opt    1000   645.647 ±   8.016  us/op
     false pattern opt    3000  2503.915 ±  36.142  us/op
     false pattern opt   10000 10338.934 ± 677.660  us/op
     false pattern jdk       3     1.486 ±   0.009  us/op
     false pattern jdk      10     4.837 ±   0.039  us/op
     false pattern jdk      30    14.782 ±   0.123  us/op
     false pattern jdk     100    50.223 ±   0.208  us/op
     false pattern jdk     300   203.604 ±   1.046  us/op
     false pattern jdk    1000   653.912 ±   2.627  us/op
     false pattern jdk    3000  2685.241 ± 164.101  us/op
     false pattern jdk   10000  9995.800 ± 899.325  us/op
```

The `trim` task is `map(String::trim)` and `pattern` task is the complex regexp replacement. On parallel tests for `trim` task JDK spliterator wins on `n <= 100`, because here less parallelism is actually better. Results of `opt` version are close to `base` (`ArrayList.spliterator`). I guess this can be ignored as sequential version for such task sizes is much faster.

The disappointing thing is that while `opt` version almost 2x faster than `jdk` on parallel pattern test, it's still almost 2x slower than `base` for `n=300..1000`.

We had some [discussion](http://mail.openjdk.java.net/pipermail/core-libs-dev/2015-July/034528.html) about this issue in core-libs-dev mailing list. Note that `Files.lines` in JDK 9 is already optimized for regular files shorter than 2Gb, now it's really parallel-friendly.

issue.title: Support StreamEx.of(Iterator) (and primitives) and optimize it for parallel processing
issue.body:
New static methods could be added:

```
StreamEx<T> StreamEx.of(Iterator<T>)
EntryStream<K, V> EntryStream.of(Iterator<Entry<K, V>>)
IntStreamEx IntStreamEx.of(PrimitiveIterator.OfInt)
LongStreamEx LongStreamEx.of(PrimitiveIterator.OfLong)
DoubleStreamEx DoubleStreamEx.of(PrimitiveIterator.OfDouble)
```

JavaDoc should mention that use of such methods is discouraged as iterator has poor characteristics and unknown size which results in poor parallel processing. However parallel processing quality might be improved using custom `UnknownSizeSpliterator` implementation (see the discussion in #3). So this spliterator should be used internally instead of JDK `Spliterators.spliteratorUnknownSize`.

Probably `StreamEx.ofLines` could also be switched to this spliterator, but additional investigation is necessary.
- [x] Draft implementation
- [x] Tests for spliterators
- [x] Tests for of(Iterator) methods
- [x] JavaDoc
- [x] Changes
- [x] Cheatsheet

issue.title: Further improvement of UnknownSizeSpliterator parallel performance
issue.body:
Investigation shows that tweaking the estimated size of USS array part may greatly improve the splitting quality making it comparable with `ArrayList`-like source (provided that getting the item from the source is relatively cheap compared to downstream processing). Thus such spliterator might become really useful for the parallel processing of unknown size sources (including `StreamEx.ofLines`, see #3).
- [x] Implementation
- [x] Benchmarks
- [x] Changes

body: I finally found a better solution to this problem. Now all the processors should be used when `ofLines` is executed and parallel performance should reach the maximum. On the other hand the general batching strategy did not change (it still starts with 1024 lines). Some minor overhead could be added when processing very long files ( > 1000000 lines ) compared to JDK implementation, but preliminary benchmarks show that it's negligible. If JDK-9 optimized Files.lines is available (when using `StreamEx.ofLines(path)`), then it will be used instead of my optimization. The code is committed and targeted to 0.5.2 release. You may test it if you want.
